[Statement 1]: Cleaner wrasse show potential as a cost-effective biological control method for sea lice.
[Statement 2]: One controlled study found cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments at controlling lice infestation.
[Statement 3]: Altering lighting is a potential cost-effective approach for controlling sea lice.
[Statement 4]: A replicated, controlled study in Norway showed lower lice numbers on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting.
[Statement 5]: Probiotics and immunostimulants reduced lice infection levels by 28% in salmon fed a diet with added beta-glucans compared to controls.
[Statement 6]: Fallowing systems showed mixed results for controlling sea lice numbers.
[Statement 7]: One study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon when using a fallowing system.
[Statement 8]: A study in Australia found no difference in lice numbers on Atlantic salmon when using a fallowing system.
[Statement 9]: Freshwater bathing provided mixed evidence for treating diseases in salmon.
[Statement 10]: The specific effectiveness of freshwater bathing against sea lice was not clearly established.
[Statement 11]: No evidence was found specifically comparing the costs of different sea lice control methods.
[Statement 12]: Biological controls and management practices like lighting alterations may offer more sustainable and potentially cost-effective alternatives to repeated chemical treatments.
